questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following fetal hormones does not play any role in fetal growth?
questions.explanation:
Growth hormone does not play any role in fetal growth, although it is present in high levels during 
the fetal period. However, it does have a role in the postnatal period. Insulin and thyroxine hormones are required for normal growth and development during late 
gestation. Glucocorticoid has a role in the prepartum maturation of organs such as liver, lungs, 
and gastrointestinal tract.

questions.question:
Question 2: A child is brought to the pediatrician for vaccination. The child is able to speak in 2-3 word 
sentences and is able to make a tower of 6 cubes. What is the expected weight of the child, if 
his development is normal and birth weight was 3 Kgs?
questions.explanation:
The child is able to make a tower of 6 cubes and speaks in 2-3 word sentences which indicates the 
child is of 2 years of age. Birth weight quadruples by the age of 2 years. Hence the child's weight 
should be 3 kgs x 4= 12 Kgs. Infants may lose up to 10% of their birth weight in the 1st week of life and regain it by their 2nd 
week.

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following statements regarding the eruption of teeth is false?
questions.explanation:
Primary teeth in the upper jaw erupt earlier than their counterpart in the lower jaw, except for 
lower central incisors and second molar. No primary teeth till the age of 13 months is called 
delayed eruption. As seen in the image below, the first primary tooth to erupt is the lower (mandibular) central 
incisor, at 5-7 months. All primary teeth erupt by 1.5–2.5 years of age. 90 
Sold by @itachibot The first secondary tooth to erupt is the first molar (maxillary or mandibular), at 6-7 years, 
followed by the lower central incisor. Causes of delayed eruption: • Idiopathic: Most common • Hypothyroidism • Hypoparathyroidism • Familial • Mechanical blockage of individual teeth

questions.question:
Question 5: A 3-year-old boy presented to the clinic for a missed vaccination. His routine anthropometric 
measurements were noted. He was found to be 90 cm tall with a lower segment of 45 cm. 
Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis in this child?
questions.explanation:
The upper segment to lower segment (U/L) ratio in this child is 1. The U/L ratio is low for his age 
which makes spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia most likely among the given options. The lower segment is defined as the length from the symphysis pubis to the floor. The upper 
segment is measured by subtracting the lower segment from the height. The U/L ratio is • 1.7 at birth • 1.3 at 3 years • 1 after 7 years • 0.9 in adults 91 
Sold by @itachibot High U/L ratio: • Rickets • Achondroplasia • Untreated congenital hypothyroidism Low U/L ratio: • Spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia • Vertebral anomalies Arm span: • Length between the tips of the middle finger of the outstretched hands is the arm span. • It is shorter than the length by 2.5 cm at birth; it equals height at 11 y and thereafter is slightly 
greater than height (usually<1 cm).

Question 6: A team participating in an Under-14 national athletics sports tournament suspects foul play 
by, a rival team member. He claims to fit the criteria for the age requirements for the 
tournament, but the opposing team does not agree. Which of the following X-ray would be 
most useful to verify the claims of the player?

options.b: X-ray of the hands and wrist
options.d: X-ray of the elbow and hip

questions.explanation:
The X-ray of choice to determine the skeletal age of a 14-year-old boy is X-ray of the elbow and 
hip. The bone age of a child indicates his/her level of biological and structural maturity. Methods used 
for bone age estimation are Gruelisch–Pyle atlas (more common) and Tanner–Whitehouse 
method. Note: There is overlap in the age ranges for X-ray of choice. Age

options.b: Lymphoid growth follows a sigmoid-shaped pattern
options.c: Perinatal period is between 28 weeks of gestation to 7 days after birth

questions.question:
Question 9: In the image given below, the weight and height of a child are plotted against his age in years. 
Identify the correct statement.

options.a: WHO growth charts used now are developed by National Center for Health Statistics (NCHS).
options.b: Short stature is defined as a height below 5th percentile.
options.c: Puberty in this child will be normal.
options.d: Bone age of this child is less than chronological age.

questions.explanation:
Bone age of this child is less than chronological age, as seen in cases of constitutional delay. As seen in the graph, the child was short initially, but the final height is within normal range. 
Hence, this child has constitutional delay. Other options: • The WHO growth charts are based on Multicentre Growth Reference Study (MGRS). National 
Center for Health Statistics (NCHS) developed growth charts that were used in the past. • Short stature is defined as a height below the third percentile or more than 2 standard deviations 
below the median height for age and gender (<-2 SD) according to the population standard. • Puberty will be delayed in this child.

questions.question: Question 10: Identify the correct statement from the following.

options.a: Children with pica are at increased risk of megaloblastic anemia
options.b: Breath-holding spells are associated with hypertonia
options.c: Thumbsucking in a child is a way of discharging tension
options.d: Bedwetting after a period of 3 months of dryness at night is called secondary enuresis

questions.explanation:
Thumbsucking in a child is a way of discharging tension. It is a self-limiting habit disorder, 
usually seen between 6 months to 2 years. Option A: Pica is persistent ingestion of non-nutritive substances for at least 1 month. It hampers 
the development of the child and requires clinical attention. Children with pica are at an increased 
risk of lead poisoning, iron-deficiency anemia, and parasitic infections. Option B: Breath-holding spells: It is preceded by a provocative event such as anger. Crying stops 
at full expiration. Child may have apnoea, cyanosis, pallor, hypotonia, or even loss of 
consciousness, and generalized tonic–clonic seizure (GTCS). Subtypes include cyanotic, pallid, and 
mixed episodes. Seizures and cardiac causes should be ruled out. Parents should be reassured 
that breath-holding spells are self-limiting. Option D: Enuresis: • When the child has never been dry, it is called primary enuresis. • When the bedwetting starts after a minimum period of six months of dryness at night, it is 
termed as secondary enuresis. • Nocturnal enuresis is caused due to maturational delay. In a normal individual, antidiuretic 
hormone (ADH) levels usually peak between 4 am and 8 am. This circadian rhythm is impaired in 
nocturnal enuresis, leading to bedwetting. • Treatment - Behavioural therapy with positive reinforcement, bladder alarms, and desmopressin 
reserved for cases resistant to behavioural therapy.

months he has developed body-rocking movements and repeats words he hears on the 
television. He doesn’t respond immediately on calling his name and also makes limited eye 
contact during interactions. Based on clinical examination you suspect autism in the child. 
Which of the following screening tools can be used to detect the boy’s condition?

The symptoms are suggestive of Autism - which is a pervasive developmental disorder 
characterized by: • Impairment in quality of social interaction • Impairment in quality of communication • Restricted, repetitive, and stereotyped patterns of behaviors and interests Common symptoms of Autism Spectrum Disorder - • Repetition of set words and phrases (echolalia) • Absent or delayed response to name being called, despite normal hearing • Reduced or absent responsive social smiling • Reduced or absent social use of eye contact • Reduced social interactions • Lacking the ability to initiate or sustain an interaction with peers or adults • Stereotypic movements and repetitive behaviors may include hand flapping, finger movements, 
body rocking, and lunging • Overly sensitive to noise, smells, or texture and may scream when they hear a siren or vacuum Modified Checklist for Autism in Toddlers (MCHAT) is a screening tool for the detection of

Question 14: A 14-year-old boy is concerned about the change in colour of his scrotum since the last few 
weeks. On examination, the boy has a dark scrotum with normal-sized testis, with coarse and 
curly pubic hair. What is the sexual maturity rating of this boy?
questions.explanation:
The stage at which the pubic hair is coarse, curly and scrotum become dark is SMR stage 4. The first visible sign of puberty in males is testicular enlargement at 9.5 years, which is a hallmark

questions.question: Question 15: Identify the correct statement.

options.a: Macrocephaly is defined as an occipitofrontal circumference greater than 3 SD above the mean
options.c: Microcephaly is defined as an occipitofrontal circumference more than 2 SD below the mean
options.d: Infants with benign familial megalencephaly have normal head circumference at birth

questions.explanation:
Microcephaly is defined as an occipitofrontal circumference more than 2 SD below the mean for 
age and sex. Macrocephaly is defined as an occipitofrontal circumference more than 2 SD above the mean for 
age and sex. Monosomy 1p36 is associated with microcephaly. Infants with benign familial megalencephaly have increased head circumference at birth. Important causes of macrocephaly: • Megalencephaly (enlargement of the brain parenchyma) • Benign familial • Neurocutaneous syndromes such as neurofibromatosis, tuberous sclerosis • Lysosomal storage diseases: Tay–Sachs, mucopolysaccharidosis, gangliosidosis • Increased cerebrospinal fluid • Hydrocephalus • Benign enlargement of subarachnoid space • Hydranencephaly (absence of cerebral hemispheres; the cranial cavity is filled with cerebrospinal 
fluid [CSF]) • Enlarged vascular compartment • Arteriovenous malformation • Subdural, epidural, subarachnoid, or intraventricular hemorrhage • Increase in the bony compartment • Bone disease: Achondroplasia, osteogenesis imperfecta • Bone marrow expansion: Thalassemia major • Miscellaneous causes • Intracranial mass lesions: Cyst, abscess, or tumor 98 
Sold by @itachibot • Raised intracranial pressure: Idiopathic pseudotumor cerebri

questions.question:
Question 16: A mother brings her baby of 14 months to the clinic after being concerned about the shape of 
the baby’s head. You are suspecting a case of craniosynostosis. The premature fusion of which 
of the following suture is seen in this child? 87 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The picture is suggestive of a child with left posterior plagiocephaly (as the left side of the head is 
flattened) which involves the premature fusion of the left lambdoid suture. In the case of a left anterior plagiocephaly, the premature fusion of the left coronal suture is seen. Other deformities of the skull: Craniosynostosis consists of premature fusion of one or more cranial sutures, resulting in an 
abnormal head shape. • Primary craniosynostosis: It results from a primary defect of ossification. • Secondary craniosynostosis: It results from the failure of brain growth. Deformity

questions.question:
Question 17: A 7-year-old boy was found to have a height for age 2 standard deviations below the median. 
Furthermore, his bone age was found to be equal to chronological age. Which of the following 
is most likely?
questions.explanation:
Familial short stature is most likely as bone age is equal to chronological age. Bone age is more than chronological age in precocious puberty. Bone age is less than chronological age in all other causes of short stature such as constitutional 
delay, undernutrition, genetic diseases, and endocrine causes. 100 
Sold by @itachibot Nutrition and Breastfeeding
